text: I'm not sure what it is that prompted your questions. I don't know of MS ever going forth with enforcing channel binding. Please post a link if you know otherwise. At one point, they announced that they would eventually enforce LDAP signing. I don't think they ever said channel binding would be enforced. In any case, they long ago decided against LDAP signing once they considered all of the third party stuff that would break. Obviously those are two different things. For signing, Windows is set because it always uses LDAP signing. I believe channel binding will be used as long as the Windows machine isn't way out of date with patches. The term "signing" can be deceiving because applications that need to make LDAP connections to AD can use LDAPS instead. I have dealt with many of these apps and they vary greatly with the amount of difficulty involved in getting them to use LDAPS. From most of the feedback I've seen, not many third party apps or OSes will be able to use channel binding. I don't know if that has changed much in the last few years. So the bottom line is that as long as you don't set your DCs to force LDAP signing or channel binding, nothing is going to change. If I'm wrong, someone please let me know.

metadata.subject: Re: [patchmanagement] LDAP Security: LdapEnforceChannelBinding
metadata.keywords: ["would eventually enforce ldap signing", "always use ldap signing"]
